title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. Character education in schools focuses on improving students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. Character education in schools aims to improve students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society through social, emotional, and ethical development. Effective character education boosts self-esteem, reduces isolation, and prevents harm to others. Character education in schools integrates positive ethical character traits into the regular curriculum and culture, increasing students' self-esteem and reducing the risk of isolation or harm to others. Schools that incorporate character education into daily activities help develop core ethical values and virtues in students, providing a model of a community with mature and responsible individuals. States and local educational agencies are increasingly promoting the implementation of character education. Successful character education initiatives are being promoted by an increasing number of States and local educational agencies, emphasizing the importance of access to effective methodologies and professional development opportunities for schools and teachers. Agencies are promoting character education initiatives, emphasizing the need for access to effective methodologies, professional development opportunities, and a central source of information for schools and teachers. As States and local educational agencies coordinate character education implementation in schools, a central source of information on initiatives and effectiveness is crucial for educating students successfully. Information on the effectiveness of Federal, State, and local educational agency initiatives, as well as the advancement of character education in schools, is essential for successfully educating students about character. The Secretary is authorized to grant a single 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information to schools on a national level. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, initiatives, and resources to schools. The Secretary can grant a 5-year grant to an organization for character education initiatives, resources, and curricula. The grantee must use the funds to develop quality character education initiatives. The grant recipient must develop initiatives promoting core ethical values, student motivation, and caring school communities. The grant recipient must use funds to develop initiatives focusing on core ethical values, student motivation, caring school communities, character education, family and community involvement, leadership, service, and teamwork. The grant recipient must develop initiatives focusing on core ethical values, student motivation, caring school communities, family and community involvement, leadership, service, and teamwork. Initiatives should also include opportunities for students to practice character lessons, involve families and communities in character education, emphasize leadership, service, and teamwork, and evaluate the effectiveness of character education programs. The grantee must evaluate the effectiveness of character education initiatives, including their impact on disciplinary referrals and teacher expectations. Information dissemination should focus on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, and making information available electronically. The grantee will use funds to collect and disseminate information on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, assessment methods, and integrating character education into educational content and reform efforts. The grantee will use funds to provide a searchable database with information on character education initiatives, assessment methods, integration into educational content, and other relevant topics for educators. The grantee will use funds to provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos, as well as a checklist for schools to assess the appropriateness of character education curricula. The grantee will provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos, along with a checklist for schools to assess the appropriateness of character education curricula. Additionally, they will offer an index of websites related to character education and telephone assistance with a toll-free access number. The grantee will offer a searchable database on character education resources, including groups, curricula, books, and initiatives, along with a checklist for schools. They will also provide an index of websites on character education and a toll-free telephone assistance service. The grantee must submit an annual report detailing their progress, including the number and types of information requests received. The grantee must report on the number, sources, and types of information requests received, identify future information needs in character education, and provide a detailed account of grant fund usage. Authorization of $750,000 for each fiscal year is provided for this purpose. The grantee must report on information needs in character education and grant fund usage. $750,000 is authorized for each fiscal year. SEC. 3. GRANT TO CONDUCT CHARACTER EDUCATION RESEARCH. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives and their success are unknown, and the needs of schools already implementing character education have not been identified. Efforts should be made to determine the extent to which schools are undertaking character education, the effectiveness of such efforts, and the extent to which Federal funds are being utilized. The impact of character education initiatives in schools is currently undetermined, and the needs of schools already implementing these initiatives have not been identified. The resources required by schools that have not yet started character education programs are also unknown. Efforts should be made to determine the extent of character education initiatives in schools, their effectiveness, and the use of Federal funds. The resources needed by schools not yet implementing character education programs are unknown. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation and research. The Secretary is authorized to make a single 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in evaluation, research, and developing character education initiatives in schools. The grant recipient must have experience in character education, developing initiatives in schools, identifying quality programs, research and publishing, and a partnership with a higher education institution. The grant recipient must have experience in character education, developing initiatives in schools, identifying quality programs, research, publishing, and a partnership with a higher education institution. The grant requirements include determining schools' character education initiatives, classifying approaches, investigating funding impact on implementation. The grant recipient must have experience in character education and developing initiatives in schools. They are required to determine the extent of character education initiatives in schools, classify approaches, investigate funding impact, and assess effectiveness. A report titled "The State of Character Education in the Nation's Schools" must be submitted annually to the Secretary. The grant recipient must assess the effectiveness of character education initiatives and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing research progress, results, future needs, and grant utilization. The grant recipient must submit an annual report detailing research progress, results, future needs, and grant utilization. Authorized appropriations are $700,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible organization" is defined as a group of organizations meeting specific requirements, including being described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and being exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of such Code. An eligible organization must meet specific requirements, including being described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, being exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of such Code, and submitting a grant application to the Secretary as required. The terms "local educational agency" and "school" are defined in the Act. The Secretary may require information. "Local educational agency" and "school" are defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
